I can't really add to the comments of the others who have spoken at great length about this film.  Suffice to say, it is my favourite of the four(so far) available, ahead of episode 1, then 4 and finally six. I'm writing this to inform others of the one jarring addition to the special edition version of this film.  I don't know if this rates as a spoiler, so a spoiler warning is in effect. The final saber fight, where luke is hanging precariously over the core of Cloud City.  In the original movie, he falls to escape Darth Vader, prefering death over betrayal of his friends.  However, in the Special Edition, why did they feel the need to make him scream?  And not only did they make him scream, they simply pasted the Emperor's death scream from Jedi in!  Just go back and watch yourself if you don't believe me.  This not only ruins the scene for me, but it detracts from the power of the ending. If they wanted to make him scream, surely it wouldn't have cost too much to get Mark Hamill in for 30 minutes?  They got him to change some of his lines on Dagobah, why not this?  Still, it's just a slight gripe, the rest of the film is excellent.  Perfect 10.

Review_Title: Best of the 4 Star Wars films to date
Review: Whenever I see a list of the greatest films of all time, Star Wars, A New Hope, deservably, is always ranked high. However, none of the other films seem to make it. Not even 'The Empire Strikes Back, which is generally regarded by fans and movie critics alike as the greatest of the series. Would ANH be so highly regarded if not for ESB? ESB added depth and emotion to the series. Star Wars was HUGE and any sequel was sure to make money. In the hands of hollywood it would have been called Star Wars 2 and would have featured an even more amazing escape from a bigger and more powerful Death Star. A meaner villain and an even more impressive final space battle. But in the hands of the master he decided to take the Star Wars universe in a new direction and expand on it. He took a risk doing this. With the exception of the lightsaber duel, nothing from the original is rehashed here. Imagine if GL needed Hollywood backing and pitched the story to some Hollywood suits, "The big battle between the Empire and Rebels takes place at the beginning of the film, not the end like in the original. The film then splits off into two parallel non-action, character driven stories and climaxes with 2 simultaneous battles. Throughout it all, the heroes are retreating and the bad guys are winning.  The movie ends with Han Solo frozen in carbonite, and shipped off to Jabba the Hutt, and the rest of the rebels are in hiding."  What Hollywood suit would have greenlighted a script that depressing. "Damn it, this is supposed to be a sequel to Star Wars, I want bad guys dying and Empirial bases blowing up and a happy ending with a cheerful ceremony." Fortunately, Lucas makes films on his own terms. The few original reviews I found from 1980 were unenthusiatic. "It has no beginning and no end and drags in the middle" was the common complaint. 20 years later it is now considered the Masterpiece of the series. Other great sequels that come to mind are 'Godfather 2', 'The Road Warrior', 'Star Trek 2', 'Superman 2' and 'Toy Story 2'. These are all sequels that refused to follow the standard sequel formula of rehashing the original.  Roger Ebert calls ESB the heart of the franchise. The excellence of ESB resonates back to ANH. Had Lucas not had a bigger story in mind and Star Wars, ANH stood on its own, I believe it would not be as highly regarded today.

Review_Title: A masterclass of Cinema and Sci-fi fantasy
Review: From start to finish it's an incredible film and really shows and pushes the boundaries of filmmaking from the era it was made. The way they do all the visual/special effects is insane and looks so beautifully well done.

Especially how Luke was being trained by Grand Master Yoda. Hell, I could go on all day, but this movie is a MUST-SEE!
There's literally nothing I can say that's not already been said. Truly the most amazing film to ever exist.

Now George Lucas has tried to cover his mistake by editing the voice of bobba fett back to an Aussie accent in the originals, if you haven't noticed then watch Empire Strikes Back whenever it comes on TV and watch it on DVD or video you will notice the change in accents. Is this a mistake or have they just developed an American accent during the 20 year period after the war? if so then that is stupid and doesn't make sense because there are different accents in stars wars not just American!

Everything is right with The Empire Strikes Back. In this classic George Lucas introduces the world to the emersive, mystical side of his world of Star Wars. Where A New Hope was somewhat shallow, plot-driven and sometimes poorly written and acted, the sequel feels like the story and characters wrote itselve, and took the character development and world-building to a whole new level in cinema history.

Review_Title: Still the greatest movie I have ever seen, still awesome!
Review: Proved that Star Wars was not a fluke - and even improved on it and expanding an already amazing universe. it was this movie that made Darth Vader the ultimate villain/movie icon (or fallen hero?), this movie that defined the force (something which many other films have tried to copy) this movie that had a main character (who was completely believable & watchable) who moved us with the magic of the force - yet was a puppet; this movie that showed us the most epic duel/showdown/cliffhanger to date; this movie that showed that Harrison Ford was a movie star - and this movie that made us all want to fly the Millennium Falcon ( the first movie spaceship to really fly), fight with a light saber and be a bounty hunter!And it still amazes me today! Oh and has the greatest soundtrack ever recorded.

The best film in the original trilogy. This movie still holds up to this day and is a joy to watch 42 years on. If you haven't watched this glorious film i suggest you do along with the other two entries in the trilogy.

***spoilers ahead***

What a remarkable film this is. Easily, the greatest of the five Star Wars films made so far and one of the greatest fantasy films of all time. I remember what a revelation ESB was when I first saw it as a child. What a contrast it was from the first film. From the offset, it was darker and more brooding and psychological. It was of a more mature nature and had the richest character development of any of the Star Wars films. In a way, I think that it was the most "realistic" of all these films, in that it was more grounded in solid emotions and there was palpable resonance to it. This truly is the film that solidified the Star Wars mythology, and it defined and molded the characters in ways that give them all deeper meaning, purpose, and motivation. Everything starts working on a whole other level. To me its all about dark family secrets lurking just beneath the surface, and you definitely feel that all throughout this film. When the awful "truth" is revealed in the end, you realize that the clues have really been there all along. Luke's anguished cry after Vader tells him that "I am your father", is not one of shock or denial, but of the acceptance of something that he has really known all along. And Vader suddenly has more form and dimension. He has a purpose (as all truly great villains must). Is he not now, after all, basically a father trying to find his children and bring them to his side? Yoda is wise and wonderful and really embodies all the magic of this modern fantasy myth. The developing romance between Han and Leia is engaging and believable. And there's real chemistry there. It's truly light years ahead of the love story between Anakin and Padme from "Attack of the Clones". On just about ALL levels, its far superior to "Clones", making the latest Star Wars release seem cold, ineffectual and flaccid. AND, most importantly...

It seems clear to me that this is the greatest movie ever for several reasons.  First of all it has great action and special effects.  Anlng with every other star wars movie, This was the benchmark for special effects upon its release. Plenty of battles on Hoth and in the asteroid field.  Great drama.  It shows the evolving relationship between Leia and Han Solo and between Luke an Vader.  It also has one of the greatest plot twist in the history of cinema which contains one of the most memorable lines in the history of cinema. And to top it off is has the greatest viliian of all time.  Darth Vader!  His pure evil is enforced throughout the whole movie by showing him kill his own admirals for thier mistakes, and through his detrusction of the rebel base on Hoth.  Which is one reason why the climax is so great in this movie.  It shows us he does have feelings when he is unable to kill Luke.  Great Irony,   Great Movie.

Review_Title: This set the tone for darker sci-fi movies...
Review: While most would consider this tame by today's standards Chapter 5 of this saga had menacing overtones, a huge twist reveal, and a not so happy ending. To me this set the tone for sci-fi movies to push the envelope not only for special effects but story structure and resolve.

Review_Title: A milestone in our film history
Review: A movie that stand as a milestone in our recent film history. It not only changed the films that where made in the 70's, it changed the genre: Science Fiction; By it's groundbreaking special effects, by it's storytelling, use of shots, etc. George Lucas proves with this film that he is a master in creating worlds. A master in telling stories and one of the founding fathers of Science Fiction and Special Effects. On a more technical base, he reinvented the use of Panavision. The movie is the second one in the Star Wars franchise. And it proves to be a promising franchise, that continues to surprise the audience.
There's no review necessary from my part and I will make this short, sweet and simple. Empire Strikes Back is so far THE best one in my opinion. That is all.

I first watched this as a kid and even then it was my favorite of the three. I don't know how to put into words why I like this one so much. Something about the flow of it and the cinematography and how the plot moves. I also like the cloud city and Luke finding out the truth finally! Plot twist! :-D lol In all seriousness tho I don't know what to say about this movie that hasn't already been said better by so many others. I just enjoy it. Its a classic. Its Star Wars. I watch it at least once a year. :)

Review_Title: the death star has been destroyed by the rebels. However the strength of the empire remains omnipotent. Its effort in finding and destroying all rebel forces has doubled.
Review: Not getting old. The immortality of a genuine argument is probably what is most looked for by directors and producers. This movie in my opinion is unarguably the clearest representation of filmographic imperishability. In this one George Lucas gathers a virtuously designed nexus between the fifth and the 6th movie of the saga. However, this movie is by no means fault of action or memorable moments. Here we discover the relationship that lies between Luke and Darth Vader. George places us in front a very decisive moral dilemma: Will young Luke grow prey of fear and hate like his father? or by the contrary, will he become a jedi?;or in other words: will he save the day and defeat Darth Vader? or will he join him and Palpatine, screwing it all up? I was glad to see that in this movie, the hard challenge to which the actors were subjected was passed by all of them flawlessly. I was specially thrilled by the way mark Hamill succeeds in showing us with great sophistication the metamorphosis Luke is undergoing, evolving from an ignorant crybaby, into a mighty and wiser jedi. The way his motifs become more altruistic and less egocentric in such an adverse situation makes us watch a man handling a light saber and no longer a boy. This simply broadens the range of ages that will be adhered to this particular movie. Carrie fisher and Harrison ford excel at their role and add the necessary spice to the film. Resorting to the child-pleasing comedy provided by C3PO or R2D2 was thankfully not a major concern in this movie.

Review_Title: The Best Movie Ever Made (Pre Special Edition)
Review: This movie is so amazing for so many reasons but the one thing I have to say is the greatest is that the bad guys are winning the entire time. Lucas had to capture his audience in the first film and no one likes a film where the bad guys wins. However once he had established the rebellion and set up the characters he was free to do some good guy bashing.

Star Wars: The Empire Strikes Back has to be easily one of my favorite movies of all time. The movie has a strong cast, a great director, and a really awesome sound track. This movie is the second one in a three part trilogy that revolves around a group of heroes and how they help save the galaxy from the tyranny of the Empire. The main characters are Luke Skywalker (Played by Mark Hamill), Han Solo (Played by Harrison Ford), and Princess Leia (Played by Carrie Fisher). George Lucas, the director and maker of Star Wars, does a fantastic job telling the story about Luke and his friends and the challenges they face. And John Williams wrote the music that, which in my opinion, helps make the movie a true epic.

Review_Title: The Most Powerful Star Wars Movie
Review: After being abruptly evicted from his Death Star digs, Darth Vader seeks out the young rebel warrior responsible, Luke Skywalker. He has plans for the boy. Skywalker, meanwhile, leaves his friends in the middle of an Imperial invasion for a crash course in Jedi Knighthood amid a desolate swamp world with only a faultfinding green gnome for company. Can Luke complete his training before Darth reels him in?

***Potential Spoiler*** Simply put, if you haven't seen it (I feel for you), wait until Luke finally confronts Vader near the end.  The ensuing conversation is WHY so many people love Star Wars.  It contains the greatest twist (in my mind) in movie history.  NOBODY could have seen it coming and if they tell you they did, they're lying.  Straight up.
I remember seeing this in 1980 and being just amazed. Fast forward to 2012, with all the big budget thrill rides, and yet, The Empire Strikes can still hold its own with any of them.
This is the turning point in the Original Trilogy films, more character development rather than action.

I remember going to the movie theater to watch the premiere of Star Wars... This experience totally blew my mind!!! I had never experienced anything quite as powerful before. I felt like similar adventures may actually be happening in other galaxies, far, far away and we think we are alone on our little planet... I obviously ran to the theater one more time as soon as The Empire Strikes Back hit the silver screen. Then that was it. From the first images, I was like in command of a Snowspeeder! This visuals were simply mesmerizing, should I say Striking! From this day, I knew I wanted to be part of something like that... one day. I am not there yet, but I am now a CG artist, working very hard at perfecting my art, looking at every detail that can make each of my model more realistic, more believable. I am also writing and producing a sci-fi movie: Apostone 'resurrection'. A mix of CG animation and acting. I am realizing my dream since I met Star Wars the sandman.
